reasoning:
Well, the first question I ask is: do I understand this business? In my sixty-plus years, I’ve stuck to consumer brands, insurance, banks and the occasional railroad. Amazon, with its sprawling e-commerce platform, cloud services, logistics network and razor-thin retail margins, sits well outside my circle of competence. If you don’t know what you’re doing, you’re just gambling – and I don’t gamble with other people’s money.

On the moat, Amazon certainly has scale advantages and a sticky Prime ecosystem, but its ROE has averaged barely 2.6% over the last ten periods and only once cracked 15%. You can have pricing power, but when you reinvest relentlessly at low returns, that moat starts leaking. AWS carries strong margins, but the conglomerate’s overall return on invested capital is under 1%. That’s too little moat for too much money tied up.

Jeff Bezos and Andy Jassy are brilliant, owner-operators. I admire their customer obsession and capital discipline — they’ve issued almost no new stock and paid no dividends. Yet reinvesting hundreds of billions at returns below even the cost of capital isn’t how I like to see capital allocated.

The balance sheet shows a debt/equity ratio north of 2.1 and inconsistent earnings growth. In ten reporting periods, total earnings rose 20.2%, but they zigzagged all over the place. Owner earnings are negative and the three-stage DCF spits out an intrinsic value that’s negative $134,000 per share. When your margin of safety is minus 108%, you’re paying for potential losses, not future profits.

Long term, Amazon will remain a force in retail and cloud, but I’d rather own a wonderful business at a fair price than a fair business at a wonderful price. Compared to Coca-Cola, Apple or GEICO – where we enjoy predictable cash flows, durable pricing power and simple economics – Amazon is a maze of unknowns.

In short, I say ‘no thank you.’ Amazon is too complex, too capital-intensive at low returns and priced without a margin of safety. I’ll keep waiting for a better opportunity – you don’t get penalized for missing out, only for losing your shirt.

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of 2.6%; High debt to equity ratio of 2.2; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of 20.2% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 0/10 periods >15%; Strong and stable operating margins (avg: 48.2%) indicate pricing power moat; High performance stability (81.7%) suggests strong competitive moat

book_value_analysis.details: Consistent book value per share growth (Buffett's favorite metric)

management_analysis.details: No significant new stock issuance detected; No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (-3.5%, 5y), Stage 2 (-1.7%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
